abstract.p: Nell Merlino letter on June 14 article on black entrepreneur Tom Cobb, part of series How Race Is Lived in America, comments on problems faced by African-American and other minority women in finding equal economic opportunity

block.p: Re ''A Limited Partnership: The Black Internet Entrepreneur Had the Idea; the White One Became the Venture's Public Face'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 14):

Now we know what someone as successful as Tim Cobb, the black entrepreneur, confronts. Imagine what happens when lower-income, African-American and other minority women, far less wired than Mr. Cobb, seek money for their low-tech family day-care or other small-business dreams. Too many financial institutions still dismiss requests for loans to start up women's small businesses.
Re ''A Limited Partnership: The Black Internet Entrepreneur Had the Idea; the White One Became the Venture's Public Face'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 14):

Now we know what someone as successful as Tim Cobb, the black entrepreneur, confronts. Imagine what happens when lower-income, African-American and other minority women, far less wired than Mr. Cobb, seek money for their low-tech family day-care or other small-business dreams. Too many financial institutions still dismiss requests for loans to start up women's small businesses.
For the sake of our economy, we must hope that Mr. Cobb's story prompts those people and institutions that are so sure the new economy is colorblind to think again.
The writer is a co-founder of Count-Me-In for Women's Economic Independence, an online micro-loan fund.
